reviewText:
This is a wonderful game. This was my first game I ever owned back when I was a child, so I have a nostalgic bias. To the review; this game from the get-go is aesthetically 200% better. It looks like any indie FPS you can buy nowadays minus a tutorial and immediate plot. I put countless hours into this game as a child and never beat it. That was back before there was internet walkthroughs and developers who thought that you (the gamer) barely passed the second grade. I recommend this game to anyone who wants an relaxing, in-depth story told to them through puzzles, journal entries, and a non-hostile environment.

Good things to say about this game:
-Beautiful
-Flashlight feature is helpful
-Easy conversion from classic point-'n'-click to real-time first person.
-Story remains intact if not more immerse
-More brainpower and problem-solving required than any game on the modern market

Bad things to say about this game:
-Suffers from massive framerate drops in real time first person. I drop from 60+ FPS to around 15-20 frequently; it's not a hardware issue either, it's a frame cap.
-First person controls are different and take some getting use to (Letting off WASD brings up a cursor)
-Not a casual adventure game; requires hours upon hours to reveal the entire story, get through each puzzle (if you're new to the game), and navigate each area.

This is a time-consuming masterpiece. Mozart is to the Classical genre of music, as Myst is to Adventure games. Very few games deserve such artistic praise, this ranks number 1 on my list.

reviewText:
A beautiful recreation of a timeless classic, realMyst: Masterpiece Edition brings a piece of gaming history to modern times.  While the graphics and sounds are completely revamped to match modern-day standards, the gameplay stays true to its original and does not fail to deliver the nostalgic Myst-feeling.

It is, admittingly, a rather peculiar game, a slow paced and thoughtful puzzler in a surrealistic setting. Its puzzles can be overwhelming at times, especially for those unfamiliar with the genre, but they always have a logical (sometimes surprisingly straightforward) solution that makes you feel really smart if you solve them on your own. But even for those non-hardcore adventure gamers among you, the game offers a built in (optional) hint system that gives you little advices without spoiling too much.

There are only few negative points that should be mentioned; The controls and movement feel a bit wonky at times and you might occasionally get stuck on objects on the ground (nothing game-breaking though), however Cyan is working on a fix for that at the point of this review. The in-game cinematics still have the low resolution from previous renditions of Myst, which seems a bit out of place considering the otherwise beautiful graphics. And the missing inventory (you can only pick up and carry one item at a time) is a rather annoying remnant from the original Myst game, often requiring an unnecessary amount of backtracking.

In summary, realMyst: Masterpiece Edition is a game that wants you to immerse yourself, absorb the scenery and use your logical thinking. If you are a fan of the Myst series to begin with, this is almost a must-have, but any other adventure fan might take a look at this as well, to get a chance to enjoy a game that wrote history in a new and stunning visual design.

The 3D controls were pretty good, if a bit awkward at first.  Going up and down a spiral staircase in a certain realm was actually rather odd.  Moving around in 3D does, imho, make the game easier as things are much easier to find and figure out than in the traditional navigation.

I also found a typo in one of the journals.  The journals are worth reading, as a kid playing the game I didn't really read for the story, just the clues and missed the whole plot and meaning of the red/blue books.

The 'final' realm is also a bit dependent on your audible skills.  I am a bit tone deaf, which made that realm a challenge.  *You definitely need sound to finish that portion of the game.*

Overall, having had played the original Myst many years (decades?) ago, this was an enjoyable second play through.

reviewText:
Vanilla Myst had two major issues, and with this game one of them has been fixed.
The first issue is the nature of the puzzles themselves. Although they are deliciously challenging at times, there is quite a bit of 'find solution, write down solution, walk across map, apply solution'. This will never be fixed, but it certainly doesn't make the game anything less than spectacular.

The other issue, and by far the most severe issue, was how old the damn game was. Assuming you could even get it to start, you had to find a legacy version of Quicktime and were playing the game in 320x240 which some monitors don't even support anymore. A side effect of it's age was the graphics quality being garbage. Usually I can overlook graphics in a well-crafted game, but when a game relies so heavily on immersion and observation, and is prerendered with zero fluidity of movement, having visuals as poor as Myst's simply detracts from the overall experience.

It is for these two reasons that I had trouble getting people into the Myst series. Riven, which is quite possibly the greatest game of all time, relies on players having experienced Myst's universe and story. So you were left with two choices: Wrestle Myst into submission and persuade yourself to beat it, where the only redeeming factor at this point is it's imperfect puzzles, or play the also-ugly and also-buggy realMyst.

With the release of realMyst Masterpiece, I can finally say that Myst is fixed. While the graphics aren't quite perfect, and there are still a few cosmetic bugs, and the puzzles are the same puzzles as ever, I feel like this game actually deserves to be Riven's prequel.

In short, there is no longer any reason why you should not play through realMyst Masterpiece and then play Riven.

Only by this understanding can you make your decision about who to trust.

reviewText:
And so we have another edition of the best-selling game of the 90s. I must say I like the fact that 20 years after initial release of Myst, we can play it again as a new, fresh game (kind of). But can we call it a good, modern game, up to today's standards? Let's find out.
Notably, realMyst from 2004 got rather low ratings, so let's also compare the Masterpiece Edition with its predecessor.

When you look at the Myst Island, first impression is very good. Textures have been updated. Water looks great, which makes for amazing landscapes, not only on Myst. When you go into other Ages, however, they seem much less polished.
Probably the worst thing are in-game videos, which are very low-res (they are just the old ones). Models are also dated, prepare to see lots of simple polyhedrons - probably that's why the game's description only mentiones updated textures. But, well, you'll also find low-res textures.
All that is to say - realMyst: ME is still an old, refreshed game, not a completely new one. It doesn't look bad, I enjoyed the views, but don't expect miracles. Also, lack of edge smoothing is disturbing.

I dare to say, there are no new games like Myst. People spent a lot of time here, trying to figure out how stuff works. It could be fascinating in the 90s to explore the Ages for months (I wish I was playing back then). Nowadays people just want quick gameplays. Frustration could be a source of realMyst's low ratings.
In this edition, some puzzles got much easier. Hard to say if it's good - they say almost nobody completed the original Myst. So maybe now people will have a chance. (Wish I didn't look at spoilers so early playing Myst for the first time, duh!) For those who know the game well (spoiler alert):
Scheme showing how to turn fortress in Mechanical is now in the journal on Myst. Receivers in Selenitic are much easier to set now, and they only have to be set roughly.

Finally, what stands between us and the Myst Ages: the interface. People were saying that realMyst's 3D environment made stuff just more annyoing. The solution came in this edition - we can now choose Free Roam mode, or classic point-and-click. I must say, clicking to walk in 3D is annoying for me, so I went free. Controls are not perfect, but I got used to them after a while.

Overally, realMyst: Masterpiece Edition is not a miracle, but definitely worth playing. If you don't know Myst yet, this edition is great for finding out what's so special about the old bestseller. If you've already been there, this visit will certainly be great.
And if such a game would be released now as a new title, without its predecessors... Nah, that couldn't happen. Nobody makes such games nowadays. Maybe that's why I love Myst so much.

reviewText:
realMyst: Masterpiece Edition is a complete overhaul of the original Myst game from 1993, porting it to a modern 3D engine that allows for free-exploration as opposed to clicking on still, 2D images. It's actually done suprisingly well and stays true to the original through-out, even including the original scenes that had used real actors. I did find the performance a little choppy in some sections but never to a point where the game was unplayable. The new graphics engine brings a new life to Myst, while my elitist self prefers the original, this looks absolutely amazing and they pretty much nailed the aesthetics of the original re-imagined in 3D.

Myst is the first entry into the series and gave birth to one of the most incredible puzzle/adventure games of all time, it has some really clever puzzles that will tap into parts of your brain that are covered with cobwebs and will force you to think not 'outside the box' but 'without the box'. The plot is one extremely immersive trip that you have to uncover yourself and there are a few Myst novels that go into it with a lot more detail.

Myst starts you off glaring at a book with a moving image of an island which sends you to the island, Myst, upon interaction with it and thats where this mind numbingly fascinating adventure begins. You soon discover that there are two books placed in a library and with exploration and interactions you discover that there are two people trapped inside them, one within each book. You'll need to collect pages of the two books to free them, which are scattered around the 'Ages' (different worlds within the game) and you'll need to solve a series of complicated, yet extremely logical puzzles to progress through these diverse and unique worlds in order to find the pages and uncover more of the plot.

Myst features some amazingly designed puzzles, you'll need to write down notes, memorize figures, find clues and memorize sounds to solve them, the levels are abstract and beautiful, each completely different from the last and you'll be able to explore and solve puzzles in which ever order of world you please. This is trully an amazing adventure which has been brought back from obscurity by Cyan and would recommend anyone interested in puzzle games or interested in trying something different to invest in it.

reviewText: Myst is pretty much the definition of a classic point-and-click game, and to an extent not much really needs to be said about it. It's the sort of game that just drops you into a strange new world without any explanation, and lets you figure out how its various mechanisms work on your own. This version is an enhanced version of the original realMyst, which itself was a 3D remake of the original Myst, allowing you to walk around like a standard first-person game instead of being locked into the usual 360 swivel-cam. The Masterpiece edition greatly improves the graphics, but at the expense of having pretty strange performance; despite my GTX 970 and overclocked i5, I barely managed 30 fps when the preset was set to Very High, but when setting the preset to Medium High (turning it to anything lower than that decreases the mouse speed, for some reason) and turning on all of the settings in the Advanced options it ran at around 70 to 100+ depending on the area. The ability to move freely increases immersion, but also makes the puzzles a bit more difficult in my opinion by making it less obvious what you can and can't interact with, which is further increased by the better graphics of this version, but I consider that to be more of a plus. realMyst might not be the version of the game that the original developer prefers, but it's the one I'd rather play.

I'm so disappointed in this rework that I could cry. I am super sad about this.

The textures are flat, the lighting is stark. The original sounds are pumped jarringly straight into your ears with no remastering, mixing, or accounting for environmental effects. The pages on the books you read are razor-edged polygons, when these books are supposed to be old and weathered and dog-eared. The models are low-poly and the bump-maps are just the original textures made black and white. The screws on the marker switches are warped and shiny blobs. Textures collide and intersect as they hit seams. The pillars in the library are models with repeating textures on them—with no wear on the corners, no dust, no visible seam! reviewText:
Oh god the nostalgia...the nostalgia man.

Myst was one of the first games I ever played as a child.  It helped shape the future of adventure games, and became the definitive PC game of the early to mid '90s, only being outsold by the Sims as late as 2002.  Myst is a timeless tale of a mysterious island filled with books that transport you to new and fantastic locales.  Ever played a game where you point and click through different scenes?  Myst probably inspired it.

It wasn't until the last few years or so before I realized just how much Myst really affected me as a gamer.  I believe that everyone's gamer identity is in part defined by the games you are first exposed to.  So it makes sense to me why I have such a love of atmosphere and immersion, because Myst had that in spades.  There's nothing quite like standing on the shores of the island, listening to the wind and the waves.

The game is primarily puzzle based, and that's where most people take issue with Myst.  The puzzles are often complicated and convuluted.  This remake edition solves some of it, but there's still a lot of head scratching.  Myst operates by its own set of rules that you have to figure out as you go along.  The game doesn't have a tutorial, or a compass, or anything telling you where to go or what to do (although this edition comes with a hint guide in case you're truly lost).  It is really a game about exploration and discovery.  And believe me, solving a puzzle on your own is a fantastic sensation.

realMyst: Masterpiece Edition may be a little pricey at nearly twenty bucks, but it all depends on your viewpoint.  For me, it was worth it.  For some just coming into the series, it might seem a little like price gouging.  But if you're interested, I highly recommend checking out this standout title from gaming's youth.  This new edition enhances the graphics and includes the free form movement from the original realMyst, making it (in my opinion) the definitive edition of Myst.  So whether you're just an old fan looking for a trip down nostalgia lane, or a new arrival, Myst welcomes you to an adventure of mystery.  Because, after all, perhaps the ending has not yet been written.

EDIT: I neglected to mention in my original review that this version of the game is sometimes janky.  It's not optimized very well at times, which might just be due to the Unity engine itself, but I can't be sure.  In any case, it's something you should be aware of if you are thinking of buying it.  I never had slowdown so bad it made the game unplayable, but it did come close in the Selenitic age.  I still consider it the definitive modern edition of the game, but it is certainly not without its faults.

reviewText:
The year was 1993. The CD-ROM format was expected to fail by analysts. There was no reason for most consumers to even purchase a CD-ROM Drive. Nearly every computer game was still being published and sold on floppy discs. Consumers NEVER had any files large than a few megabytes to store. Video on computers weren't really a thing. Nobody had digital camers or camcorders. There were no vast amounts of photos to store. Heck, the average hard drive at the time was smaller than a CD-ROM's 700 MB. Usually half that size. There were virtualy no reasons at all why a consumer would ever need a CD reader in their computer, unless they wanted to play music over their PC speakers. And who would want to do that? Most experts expected the CD-ROM to die as a format.

And then Myst was released.

Looking back at the original game, it looks primitive. It's barely anything more than a bunch of pictures you click through and interact with to solve puzzles. There were a few videos and the audio was ever present, but that was it.

However, at the time, this was amazing. There weren't many games that offered a beautiful first person view like this. Even though the game consisted entirely of pre-rendered pictures, the game really made you feel like you were there. The developers were forced to create wonderful ambient sounds and a deep enthralling theme and story to really suck you in. The game was met by critical reception and acclaim.

And it saved the CD-ROM format. After Myst, EVERYONE was releasing their game on CD. It was a truly successful game, even netting it it's own parody game in the form of Pyst, developed by Parrotty Interactive, starring John Goodman.

The year was 1997.

I was eight years old and my dad had purchase our first computer. I can still remember watching him play. He LOVED the game. I think he spent hours reading the in-game books, pouring over puzzles, and making notes in his little Myst notebook. I grew up playing the original Myst and all of it's remakes. However, it's been around 14 years since I last played the game.

realMyst: Masterpiece Edition is an excellent modern interpretation of the original realMyst that was an excellent then-modern interpretation of the original Myst. Unfortunately the original realMyst lags horribly on Windows 7 and the other Myst remakes crash a lot, so this is your only bet.

It's a beautiful game, with all of the original depth, originality, and puzzly goodness of the original Myst and realMyst. Except this games has Anisotropy! And grass!

Truly, the graphics are stunningly beautiful, I can't say that enough. And the day/night cycle really makes the island feel more alive than it did before. Now, if they'd just patch in some weather effects.

However, the optimization of the graphics and performance is a bit poor. My laptop is by no means a powerhorse, however I have no problem running Skyrim or GTA IV at medium graphics. realMyst ME doesn't do so well on my computer. Anything mid-range or higher causes my FPS to drop pretty quickly. However, the game is still beautiful and an improvement at the lower settings.

The story to this game is basic, as it is a product of it's time. There was only so much room on CD-ROMs! Speaking of which, the game is also a bit short. Your hour will vary depending on how clever you are or if you've played Myst before. I, surprisingly, remembered a lot more than I thought I would and I finished the game shortly under ten hours. But your mileage really may vary. It takes a while to really learn what to do when starting out. You have to read the in-game books and really get inside your head a bit to figure it out. Don't rush in and give up on each puzzle after a minute if the solution isn't apparent. Think about what you've seen or read and see where it might fit into the world or on each level.

This game is a classic and monstrously fun. If you enjoy it, make sure to look out for the Starry Expanse Project who are currently making realRiven, the sequel to Myst. Also, the original Riven is on Steam and doesn't seem to share the compatibility issues the other Myst titles do.

Really, it's not a bad deal for the price, especially if you own the original realMyst, giving you the 33 % discount. Enjoy the game!

A year or so ago I was feeling nostalgic, and I attempted to load up my old copy of the original realMyst (from disc). Sadly, the game simply won't run on a modern machine without constantly crashing, and I gave up hope of experiencing the game again. So I was all the more delighted when I found out about realMyst: Masterpiece Edition, which I picked up the day it was quietly released on Steam. I'm glad to say that this game has all the greatness of the original, with the added bonus of better graphics and the inclusion of the original game's artwork.

For the uninitiated, realMyst is the 3D recreation of the original Myst game, which was released all the way back in 1993. Once an adventure created through still images and small inset videos, the world is fully eplorable and features all the neat things one expects to see in modern 3D game worlds, thanks to the Unity game engine. Added ambient effects include a day/night cycle and weather on Myst and many of the Ages, motion blur, depth of field, and a toggleable flashlight. It's also possible to set the game to jump between all the camera angles from the original game, but transition in 3D between clicks. It's a little bit bumpy at times, but helps strike a good balance between the new graphics and the underlying game of the past.

All the familiar sound effects and music from the original game are here as well, only in higher fidelity.

I have only minor complaints with realMyst: ME - mostly surrounding disparities between the control mechanics of certain puzzles, but none of which are really worth mentioning here. I also feel like some of the textures and 3D models could have been created at a higher resolution in places, but overall, things look pretty good.

I definitely recommend realMyst: Masterpiece Edition. It's a mostly faithful remake of Myst, and a great way to see the game realized on modern hardware, for fans of the series and newcomers alike.

reviewText:
I'm playing this right now and I'm very impressed.

The Myst games are still to this day very unique games. These games have always been about discovery, exploring very well crafted and believable alien worlds, and figuring out how the environments, natural and man-made structures in these worlds work. Learning the backstory and lore of each world also adds a lot to the experience (in the games this is usually done by reading journals). For me, they are a great and relaxing experience of discovery, and I wish there were more games like this.

So far I've explored Channelwood, Stoneship age and Myst Island, and I believe this game is to date the best representation of the worlds of Myst 1. The game has greatly enhanced textures, lighting, shadows and water compared to the original Real Myst, and the fact that you can move freely and that the worlds are much more dynamic compared to the original Myst adds a lot to the experience. The worlds are now more believable than ever, with great attention to detail: the day/night cycles are amazing to watch, the sky, moon, clouds, lighting, water, dense vegetation, and several nice touches like different elements appearing at night... the flashlight is also a nice touch.

The main negative aspect of the game for me has already been pointed out by others, and that is the bad performance. The game indeed seems to be poorly optimized, and sometimes it stutters briefly. But it is not so bad as I have everything maxed out at 1920x1200 and in general it runs fairly well on my computer. I seem to get an average of 30fps, which is perfectly playable for this kind of game. I have an i7-2600k@4.4GHz and a GTX 560Ti (I don't know if the game is more cpu bound or gpu bound, and from what I've read others seem to be getting a worse experience). I haven't experienced any bugs or crashes.

All in all, I think this game is well worth it for any fan of Myst.

reviewText: This is the best remake of Myst out there at the moment, and the definitive playable rendition of the game by my reckoning.  Myst is one of the most accessible classics in the point-and-click adventure genre, emphasizing with its sheer simplicity the joy of the exploration and puzzle-solving without ever coming off as overly contrived or campy.  The visuals are striking, the worlds are rich with lore and characterization, the central murder mystery is compelling and subtle, and the puzzles are never so abstruse as to be unsolvable (as Riven, Myst's sequel, sometimes errs).  For those familiar with the Myst games, realMyst: Masterpiece combines the HD graphic quality of Myst: Masterpiece edition with the full 3D world offered by realMyst (including Rime, the extra age, and day/night progression in all the ages), and does so quite successfully.  The game gives you the option whether to play in full 3D (which is pretty well-executed, though it can be glitchy in places), or according to the game's original advance-by-clicking controls, offering hard-core Myst fans an experience more true to the original game.  The visuals are updated across the board, and many nice touches have been included in this edition that enhance (in my opinion) the Myst experience.  In short, this is the new Gold Standard for Myst, and I highly recommend the game to everyone: gamers, non-gamers, and Myst fans alike.

So, having walked around a lot and been unavoidably beeped at by one puzzle over thirty times (urgh!) I don't really know that I want to go on.

The controls aren't anything to write home about either. For moving around you have the choice of either Classic Myst or Free Roam modes. Classic Myst just means moving around on rails and clicking to either move forward or turn, and it just felt clunky and restrictive and didn't always go where I wanted it to. As for Free Roam, well, as on the tin it's a lot more freeing and you can move around a lot more smoothly, but it's also a bit harder to interact with the environment and I'd often find myself trying to flick a switch from just a little too far away and having to readjust my distance and try again.

Never mind that I've already had the game glitch on me once already switching between the two modes!

...

And now I have a great nostalgic urge to find a copy of Zork: Grand Inquisitor (which I would recommend playing instead) so I can wash the taste of this clunky game and it's clunky interface out of my brain, but that might just be the boredom and exasperation talking.


EDIT: Well, I managed to finish it... and I guess I'm mostly ambivalent. It does probably have a nice feel in places, but I found the controls a bit lacking; the puzzles solving to be about 90% drudgery and about 10% thinking (some of them you can even solve almost by accident); some of the sound effects to be a little grating; and the hammed up poor quality FMV acting to be a bit underwhelming and jarring.

As a puzzle game (and I guess as a game in general) I'd probably fail it, and I don't know that it's worth the asking price, but maybe you can just enjoy wandering around the levels? reviewText:
Ok. Where to start. I'm going to approach this in chronological order of my

thorough dissapointment with this title. My first wave of frustration eminated

from the lack of an options menu right at the beginning. I like to set my

resolution at least before starting a new game, so I had to watch the nice intro in

an eye wrenching 1280x720, which was a little annoying but overall not a huge

deal. After spawning in the world a menu comes up and tells you that you have a

choice between free roam and and classic mode, awesome. Naturally, I pick free

roam, because nostalgia's great and everything but classic mode really defeats the

purpose of playing a real time version of Myst. Walking around in free roam was

terribly confusing at first and didnt seem to make any sense, but what I figured

out is that if you're standing still you have to hold down the right mouse button

to look. But you can look freely without doing that while moving. This is a

terribly unintuitive control mechanic that makes free roam into a kind of mental

gymnastic constantly trying to remember to hold down the mouse button every

time you stop for half a second. It is the most pointlessy alien and baffling first

person mechanic I've ever played. It's like Cyan has been sealed away in a glass

dome for the last 20 years and essentially invented their own control mechanic

based on what they knew from developing the orginal Myst and didnt bother at all

to take an example from literally any other well designed first person game. It's

also worth noting that when holding down the right mouse button, not only is it

uncomfortable to hold it down while moving the mouse, the sensitivity is

inexplicably lower which adds a new variable of unnessecary awkwardness into

this madman's equation. In line with my frustration with the controls is the fact

that there seems to be mouse acceleration that cant be disabled. I personally view

mouse acceleration with the same burning hostility that I would normally reserve

for someone who had just burned my house down and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ on my dog. And I

can't be the only one who feels this way so it would be nice to have a little

checkbox or something like all of the FPS's ever that have a mouse-acceleration

feature. You know, just a thought. Now, that that's out of the way let's talk about

the engine. I've never been overly impressed with the Unity engine, and personally

would not choose to develop in it myself, but I really want to believe it can be

used more efficiently than this. The fan for my decent graphics card that can run

Crysis 2 with no real problems was screaming at full speed after about 2 minutes.

I don't know if Cyan develops their real time titles in house but theyve never

seemed to reflect a firm grasp on how to develop assets for a games engine.

Theyve always seemed to approach it with the same technique you would use for

production rendering, in the 90's no less, going completely off the chain with

texel density and poly count for example, yet making no use of masking or

layering or anything of the sort that a modern node based shader editor can do to

hide atrociously tiling textures. Foliage density is unneseccarily higher than a

crack head fresh out of rehab, and I noticed a couple instances of vertex normals

being softened when they clearly didnt need to be which is just plain sloppy. I also

have a sneaking suspicion that they took some of the textures from the 2000

version of realmyst and hastily ran them through crazy bump. I love the original

Myst. It is a masterpiece, but this just seems like a sloppy insult to the original,

which is exactly what I thought of the original realMyst from 2000. I hate to say

this, because Myst is so close to my heart, but I cannot reccomend dropping 17

dollars on this mess of a game. If you're going to remake a classic for a 20th

anniversary, have the decency to do it right.

For those unfamiliar with the game, Myst is a classic first-person point-and-click puzzle game, originally released in 1993.

Myst series is set in an interesting universe where different worlds can be visited through specially-written books, and this is exactly what you'll be doing throughout the game. Each world has a unique theme and a set of puzzles to solve, but rather than puzzles being your typical logic minigames - they rely observation. Pulling random levers, pushing buttons and trying to figure out what they do is what Myst puzzles are all about. The game itself is actually very short and can be beaten in under an hour if you know what you're doing.

.

realMyst: Masterpiece Edition is a faithful remake of the game. Not without flaws, but certainly worthy of a recommendation. Its new modern features and visual effects make the experience even more immersive, while doing a great job preserving the charm and aesthetic of the original game. Free-roam controls add complete freedom of movement, while classic control scheme can also be enabled at any time.
The game doesn't always run well, and compared to some of the modern games of the same genre its visuals certainly lack consistency and polish. However compared to original Myst it looks and plays much better.

-----------

I previously criticized realMyst:ME for somewhat awkward controls, crashes, poor performance and visuals while better than the original - still not good enough to justify the low framerates even on a high-end machine. Thankfully, the 2.0 update brought improvements to all of those areas.

- While the game still suffers from low framerates in some areas - reducing the visual quality does improve it significantly. This wasn't the case prior to the patch and the game would stutter even on low settings.

- Model and texture quality is very inconsistent throughout the game. In some areas the game looks better than even modern AAA games, while in others the model and texture quality looks 15 years out of date. Prior to the patch though, the latter was a much more common occurence.

10/10 would play again. Brought me back to '99 when my sister and I struggled for ages to try to get through the original Myst. We never made it, lol (Being 9 and 7 years old respectively).\nMind was blown about how much I didn't know or understand about the story, but I'm glad I got this version to finish it and to fully understand and appreciate the story.\nI'll be looking forward to Riven next.

The original Myst holds a special place for me. It was one of the first PC games I ever played.
An open world first-person puzzle game that drops you onto a mysterious island and you basically have to figure everything out on your own.

realMyst: Masterpiece Edition is a remake of the game using a newer graphics engine. Overall the game is true to the original but new features such as an option to walk around in real time (or stay with traditional point-and-click), a day/night cycle for the Ages, and a few hidden tie-ins to the Myst Novels and Riven.

Also for veterans of the original game, a brand new Age to explore.

If you've NEVER played this game, but enjoy first-person puzzles, I recommend giving it a try.

tl;dr version: Highly recommended if you like adventure games and/or puzzles, and if you don't rage on non-major technical issues.
--------------------------------

Since I'm mostly used to point-and-click or modern adventure games, Myst was a new experience for me. It's a great concept- the player has to rely on visual and auditory observations to solve some large-scale puzzles, which are all completely logical and range in difficulty from easy to medium-hard (but I've played quite a lot of adventure games and am used to them; newcomers to adventure gaming may find the puzzles harder, but still doable). There is no pixel-hunting and no inventory system, which automatically dispenses with inventory item combination puzzles found in most adventure games.

The developers suggest playing the game as if the players were actually present in the Myst universe, for a fully immersive experience and to better appreciate the story. Therefore I recommend playing Myst when you have quite a bit of spare time and are mentally relaxed. This is not the sort of game you'd want to play to take a break from your hectic activities or in the midst of a busy time to relieve stress. I made that mistake and my general attitude was just to plough through all the puzzles. Nevertheless, even though I didn't pay much attention to the story (or the environmental story-related clues), I found it fairly intriguing.

The environments are simultaneously strange and beautiful, and have certain mystic feel to them (probably why the game is called Myst?). There are not a whole lot of things to interact with, which I think is very good, because that means there's very little noise in terms of puzzle-solving; most of the things the player can interact with are related to some puzzle or the other. The music and soundscapes are soothing and appropriate to the environments, especially in Rime age.

Now for some technical issues- first of all, realMyst: Masterpiece Edition is a remastered edition (graphics/interface overhaul) of realMyst, which itself was a remastered edition of Myst. The masterpiece edition also has a free roam feature. In the previous versions, the player had to click on a place the go there and the field of view was quite limited, which may have been restrictive but was not necessarily a bad thing. However, mouse movement in free roam view is very clunky. There are no subtitles, which makes it hard to listen to the characters' monologues, and there are no options to adjust the music level. The graphics aren't -that- good and the game suffers from poor optimization.

Still, I highly recommend it for adventure gaming or puzzle aficionados who don't mind the above-mentioned issues (plus RMME supports achievements and trading cards, and has additional puzzles to Myst or realMyst).

I've been playing Myst and its respective sequels since the game first came out for Windows 3.11 in 1993.  I gave realMyst: Masterpiece Edition a spin to see the changes.

The greatest improvement made in this edition over the first realMyst is that the virtual boundaries were put back.  Whereas with the first realMyst, the 'openness' made it more likely to miss items you needed to pass for the Myst storyline, Masterpiece Edition replacing the boundaries puts the player back on the path of the story.

The graphics are an improvement.  While they aren't as dynamic as could be expected from games today, they are a credit to the realism of Myst Island.  Myst V: End of Ages is the only game that has a more realistic rendering of Myst Island.

The one item that made realMyst an absolute failure still plagues Masterpiece Edition: Performance lags.  Even with the adaptable graphics disabled and with the settings set to low, an i7 16GB RAM with a 1GB graphics card, the game lags considerably. The original Myst holds a special place for me. It was one of the first PC games I ever played.
An open world first-person puzzle game that drops you onto a mysterious island and you basically have to figure everything out on your own.

realMyst: Masterpiece Edition is a remake of the game using a newer graphics engine. Overall the game is true to the original but new features such as an option to walk around in real time (or stay with traditional point-and-click), a day/night cycle for the Ages, and a few hidden tie-ins to the Myst Novels and Riven.

Also for veterans of the original game, a brand new Age to explore.

tl;dr version: Highly recommended if you like adventure games and/or puzzles, and if you don't rage on non-major technical issues.
--------------------------------

Since I'm mostly used to point-and-click or modern adventure games, Myst was a new experience for me. It's a great concept- the player has to rely on visual and auditory observations to solve some large-scale puzzles, which are all completely logical and range in difficulty from easy to medium-hard (but I've played quite a lot of adventure games and am used to them; newcomers to adventure gaming may find the puzzles harder, but still doable). There is no pixel-hunting and no inventory system, which automatically dispenses with inventory item combination puzzles found in most adventure games.

The developers suggest playing the game as if the players were actually present in the Myst universe, for a fully immersive experience and to better appreciate the story. Therefore I recommend playing Myst when you have quite a bit of spare time and are mentally relaxed. This is not the sort of game you'd want to play to take a break from your hectic activities or in the midst of a busy time to relieve stress. I made that mistake and my general attitude was just to plough through all the puzzles. Nevertheless, even though I didn't pay much attention to the story (or the environmental story-related clues), I found it fairly intriguing.

The environments are simultaneously strange and beautiful, and have certain mystic feel to them (probably why the game is called Myst?). There are not a whole lot of things to interact with, which I think is very good, because that means there's very little noise in terms of puzzle-solving; most of the things the player can interact with are related to some puzzle or the other. The music and soundscapes are soothing and appropriate to the environments, especially in Rime age.

Now for some technical issues- first of all, realMyst: Masterpiece Edition is a remastered edition (graphics/interface overhaul) of realMyst, which itself was a remastered edition of Myst. The masterpiece edition also has a free roam feature. In the previous versions, the player had to click on a place the go there and the field of view was quite limited, which may have been restrictive but was not necessarily a bad thing. However, mouse movement in free roam view is very clunky. There are no subtitles, which makes it hard to listen to the characters' monologues, and there are no options to adjust the music level. The graphics aren't -that- good and the game suffers from poor optimization.

Still, I highly recommend it for adventure gaming or puzzle aficionados who don't mind the above-mentioned issues (plus RMME supports achievements and trading cards, and has additional puzzles to Myst or realMyst).

A walk down memory lane. I remember playing the original MYST a good 20 years ago back when I had my first CD-Rom computer. The game intrigued me with its photo realistic settings and complex puzzle solving. A classic through and through. Now with today's technology, we can finally explore the worlds of MYST in full 3D movement; something many have pined for since the game's advent. It is well worth it with Day/Night cycles, some weather effects, and improved visuals. Some may be turned off by the controls, but there is an option to play it oldschool style by just clicking where you want to go. Fans are more likely to enjoy this, but newcomers should enjoy it too. Let's hope the other games in the MYST series get this treatment. Would totally buy a realRiven if it existed.
My most fav game of all time

An old, but not dated puzzle game that really holds its own despite the test of time. It still lives up to today's standards, and the lore of this whole series is incredibly deep and rich. Especially nowadays, where games aren't meant to be difficult, MYST is a welcome challenge, as it will keep you thinking and struggling, and the struggle only makes solving the puzzles even more gratifying. Rarely will you find the solution to something simply written down, and if you're playing through it for the first time, you could spend months just exploring the beautiful worlds in MYST. The only thing I can say is keep a journal while playing, you'll want to write down what you're doing and planning on doing so you don't lose your train of thought, and sometimes simply writing down what you've done will spark a thought on what to do next you wouldn't have thought of otherwise. Plus, there are plenty of things you'll want to have recorded for later, such as number sequences and such. Believe me, this game is difficult, if I hadn't kept a journal while playing, I wouldn't have completed it, but that difficulty could hardly be called a con. If you like puzzle games, good story, or are simply tired of multiplayer and simple games, you should definitely give MYST a try. The updated graphics in this version are worth the extra money (plus there's some extra content that I won't spoil here), trust me.
It's pretty much the game everyone knows and loves, but played in a modern style.  You can walk almost anwhere freely, and the achievements allow you to find things that you may have skipped over.

v2.0 is a great improvement - the right-click mouselook option solves the biggest issue I had with the game, making navigation as smooth as it should be. Thank you!

There are still a couple of rough edges - most notably, changing the color of the crystals in Ryme requires click-and-hold rather than simply hovering as in the original realMyst, and there's no intuitive way to discover that. I had to look it up after assuming the game was bugged. Speaking of original-flavor realMyst, I also miss the day-night cycle in Selentic. The new skybox is cool, but I'm not sure it's worth losing that beautiful red-to-purple-to-black twilight.

All that said, this is an absolutely beautiful game, superior to the original realMyst in pretty much every way not mentioned above, and should now be considered the definitive version of the game.

I mostly enjoyed Myst (realMyst: Masterpiece Edition). It has a lot of interesting puzzles (some much more difficult than others), and doesn't explicitly tell you how to solve any of them (or even really give you hints unless you consult an ingame advice book). This is both a good thing and a bad thing, in my opinion. It allows the player to feel a sense of accomplishment when they make progress, but can occasionally cause the player to feel frustrated and lost - then again, I imagine that's the sense the developers wanted to portray at points in the game. Despite this being the remastered version of Myst, I still feel like parts of the game haven't really aged well. For example, many of the clicking mechanics feel off, some of the cutscenes are extremely low-quality, and the free-roam mode doesn't always control well (but is still much better than the point-and-click mode). Overall, there were some parts of the story that I didn't like, but the different worlds and puzzles made the game pretty interesting.

reviewText:
After nearly 18 years, I have finally managed to complete one of the first Windows-based games I ever played.

When I began the original Myst as a kid, I was clearly stumped by the (then) challenging puzzles, and never made it past the Mechanical age, let alone completed the game.

Being not only to complete the game, but be able to move around in a (now) normal fashion satisfied a need I wasn't aware I carried for two decades.

For those that still wish to complete what they never finished as a child, this is the game for you. Otherwise, this is a hit-or-miss depending on how much you enjoyed things like Ether One or similar slow-pace puzzle games.

This game brought back a whole lot of nostalgia for me. My dad used to play it back when I was a kid and when I asked him to play, I got no where. Definately not a kid game; not because it is graphic, which it is not at all, but because of the percise logic that this game demands from you. However, I resorted to watching my dad play it hours on end. The mysterious storyline and the music is captivating. I've been looking for it all over since I'm a lot older and I own a Mac (it used to only be on PCs). I just beat the game, but if it wasn't for the hints, I'd still be banging my head on my desk. What I appreciated is that they put hints/clues that did not give you direct answers unless you really wanted them. They gave you clues or thoughts to help trigger solutions to problems you might be facing.

You start off this game by entering this Age called Myst and you just have to explore since you don't know how or why you got there. If you liked Amnesia, which starts the same way and also requires you to explore to find clues and requires reading, this is a great game. However, it is NOT as dark as Amnesia. It is more Sci-Fy then Horror and there are no monsters jumping out at you. But this game can be very eerie, simply because you are alone. There's no other physical beings around you, just their stories that have been left behind. It also requires you to figure out who and what to trust based on your judgment. There's 4 possible endings to the game.

If you like strategy or findings clues and putting one and two together, get this game. Some of the visuals changed from the original PC, but it was still satisfying for me. There's so much thought and logic put into the puzzles in this game, which can make it VERY challenging.

Will forever recommend.

I still remember this game when it came out in 1993. It was such a great looking game and created such a buzz that there was even an hour long program discussing the game and showing some of the gameplay and features. It was the first game I got when I bought my first computer in 1995. It has been 17 years since I last played the game.
Now, here is realMYST. Much has changed from the original game. You can now play in free roam mode (classic mode still available for those who prefer, but if you are trying to get the achievements, you must play in free roam mode or you won't get many of them) which lets you look and move in 360 degrees. Graphically, it's not the revelation it was in 1993, but still looks solid. The music and sound effects are still the same with a few extra things thrown in. Still brings up the great nostalgic feeling I had back then. It has been awhile, so I don't remember much, so this game remains a solid challenge.
The music and atmopshere of the game are what sill amaze me along with a strange and somewhat creepy story and adventure that you are lead on. Upon completion the game, you are now granted acces to another age called Rime. This is a very short and quite easy age, but the setting and a couple of smale things you can do are pretty cool, but pretty much a useless age. Pretty much a short part just before the Age of Riven. Only good if you wanna get the last 3 achievements done.
Anyways, still a solid game for the right price and a good 10-12 hours of gameplay, as long as you can solve the puzzles and figure out what to do next. Good luck and good clicking.

reviewText:
I never got to play Myst when it was originally released so it was nice to get the oppurtunity now. For a 20 year old game they've done a nice job of making it look good. This game just drops you onto Myst island with no hand holding advice about what to do. You need to explore and figure things out. I really liked the puzzles in this game. Theres no obscure ridiculous ones. They all felt intuitive and if you explore your surroundings enough you'll eventually figure out the solution. The game really does a great job of giving subtle hints and clues. ( Thats not to say i didn't need to google a hint every now and again).

Good points:
- Nice remastered graphics
- The islands in the game make for a very memorable setting. They seem so unique and unusual that it fits the game perfectly
- Brilliant puzzles that are intuitive enough that they dont frustrate.

Bad points:
- The free roam controls felt a bit fiddly when walking about

Overall this is a great game that im glad i finally got to play. If you havent ever played this game it's worth picking up this edition. Also worth mentioning if your completely stuck on a puzzle, try the Myst guide on Universal Hints System instead of just googling the answers. It'll give you useful hints without spoiling the answer as solving the puzzles yourself, even with a hint or two, is more enjoyable then just getting the direct solution.

I eventually borrowed a friend's copy of Myst in 2002 or so and played it and loved it. I researched into the series and found out there was a 3D remake of Myst called realMyst. I found a copy of it at Staples (lol) and played the crap out of it. Even though it was fun, you could tell there were issues with the controls and the game had many glitches.

But this right here? THIS is what Cyan should have made when the timing was right. I LOVE that you can play with the old point and click controls, because I was very fond of those controls in the past. I just finished this for the first time and did it pretty quick because I remembered all of the puzzle solutions, but it was still just as fun as I remembered.
